sen.j: 山槐記（さんかいき）は、中山忠親の日記。
sen.e: Sankaiki is Tadachika NAKAYAMA's diary.
Sankaiki is the name given to the diary of Tadachika NAKAYAMA.
Sankaiki is the name given to the diary of Tadachika NAKAYAMA.

sen.j: 中山忠親は平安時代末期から鎌倉時代初期の公卿で内大臣を務めた人物で、書名の「山槐」とは忠親の家号「中山」と、大臣家の唐名（槐門）を合わせたものに由来する。
sen.e: Tadachika NAKAYAMA was a Court noble from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period and served as Naidaijin (Minister of the Palace), and the book title '山塊 (Sankai)' derived from the combination of '中山 (NAKAYAMA)', which was Tadachika's Yago (family name), and the Chinese name of house of minister (塊門 Kaimon).

Tadachika NAKAYAMA was a court noble who lived from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period and served as Naidaijin (Minister of the Palace); the name given to his diary (which is written as '山塊' in kanji) is derived from a combination of the last kanji of Tadachika's yago (family name), which is written as '中山' in kanji, and the first kanji of the Chinese name given to the office of minister ('塊門', which is pronounced "Kaimon").

Tadachika NAKAYAMA was a court noble who lived from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period and served as Naidaijin (Minister of the Palace); the name given to his diary (which is written as '山塊' in kanji) is derived from a combination of the last kanji of Tadachika's yago (family name), which is written as '中山' in kanji, and the first kanji of the Chinese name given to the office of minister ('塊門', which is pronounced "Kaimon").

sen.j: 現存する伝文によれば、記載時期は仁平元年（1151年）から建久5年（1194年）までの40年間あまりである。
sen.e: According to an existent statement, it was written from 1151 to 1194, for about 40 years.
sen.cmt: 定訳不明 「伝文」 statementとしました。
sen.e: According to an existent document, it was written over the course of about 40 years, from 1151 to 1194.
According to an existent document, it was written over the course of about 40 years, from 1151 to 1194.

sen.j: 詳細な記事が多いが、欠失部分も少なくない。
sen.e: It carries detailed articles, but not a few parts are lost.
It contains a large number of detailed entries, but quite a few parts have been lost.
It contains a large number of detailed entries, but quite a few parts have been lost.

sen.j: 忠親は後白河院や源頼朝に重用され、日記の現存期間は平氏の興隆から全盛、滅亡の時期にあたる。
sen.e: Tadachika was given important positions by Goshirakawain and MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, and the diary's existent period was from the time of prosperity, golden days and to the fall of the Taira clan.
Tadachika was given important posts by Goshirakawain and MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, and the diary's existent period stretches from the Taira clan's rise, through its golden days, to its fall.
sen.cmt: Changed "was from" to "stretches from", changed "the time of prosperity, golden days and to the fall of the Taira clan" to "the Taira clan's rise, through its golden days, to its fall".
sen.e: Tadachika was given important posts by Goshirakawa-in (the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa) and MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, and the diary's existent period stretches from the Taira clan's rise, through its golden days, to its fall.
sen.cmt: 後白河院 に補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 平氏政権時代から治承・寿永の乱での東国情勢などについて独自の記事も多く、重要史料として扱われている。
sen.e: It has a lot of its own articles on the situation in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan) from the time of the Taira clan's government to Jisho-Juei War and is treated as an important historical material.

It has many unique articles on the situation in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan) from the time of the Taira clan's government to the Jisho-Juei War, and is treated as an important historical resource.
sen.cmt: Replaced "a lot of its own" with "many unique", inserted "the", inserted comma, changed "material" to "resource".
sen.e: It has many unique articles on the situation in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan) from the time of the Taira clan's government to the Jisho-Juei War, and is treated as an important historical resource.

sen.j: 保元の乱・平治の乱の記事は欠けているが、治承2年（1178年）の安徳天皇誕生、同4年（1180年）の即位、元暦元年（1184年）の後鳥羽天皇の即位と大嘗会の記事は緻密で、忠親が朝儀や政界の情勢に通じていたことが分かる。
sen.e: Although it lacks an article on Hogen and Heiji no ran (Rebellion of Hogen and Heiji), the articles on the birth of Emperor Antoku in 1178, his enthronement in 1180, the enthronement and Daijoe (banquet on the occasion of the first ceremonial offering of rice by the newly-enthroned emperor) of Emperor Gotoba are precise, which shows that Tadachika was familiar with chogi (ceremony at Imperial Court) and the situation of political world.

sen.cmt: Inserted "the", inserted "the", inserted "and", changed "situation of political world" to "political situation".

sen.cmt: 保元の乱・平治の乱→Hogen War, Heiji War としました。1184を追加しました。

sen.j: 平重盛の出家、平清盛による大輪田泊の改修、以仁王の挙兵、富士川の戦いなどにおいて、平家物語や源平盛衰記などの軍記物語とは異なる記述があり、史実の相違を示している。
sen.e: It has different descriptions of TAIRA no Shigemori's becoming a priest, the repairing of Owada no tomari (Owada port) by TAIRA no Kiyomori, the Rising of Prince Mochihito, the Battle of Fujigawa and so on from those in other war chronicles such as Heike Monogatari(The tale of the Heike) and "Genpei Seisui ki" (Rise and Fall of the Minamoto and the Taira clans) and shows difference in historical evidence.

Its descriptions of TAIRA no Shigemori's entry to the priesthood, the repair of Owada no tomari (Owada port) by TAIRA no Kiyomori, the uprising of Prince Mochihito, the Battle of Fujigawa and so on differ from those in other war chronicles such as Heike Monogatari (The Tale of the Heike) and "Genpei Seisui ki" (The Rise and Fall of the Minamoto and the Taira clans), and it displays differences in historical evidence.
